Releases.title: A/B (expanded)
Releases.text: All music & photos by Justin Morgan. Tracks recorded at home studios in Delaware & Pennsylvania USA from 2014 ~ 2017. Limited Edition cassette originally released on Body Control Records (BCT003). Updated 2018 digital edition includes 7 extra tracks from the same recording sessions.

Releases.title: Normal People
Releases.text: Music set aside for years now finds a collective home as Digalogue, a new alias for artist Justin Morgan on Soho Six Records. The mini-album, Normal People, explores the electro side of techno with sounds of FM and subtractive synthesis.

Releases.title: Summer Seventeen
Releases.text: Pulling from classic 90s/00s vibes, Rusuden releases three Techno tracks recorded in June/July of 2017.  Summer Seventeen EP provides some great dance floor friendly jams, easily mixed into any acid DJ set.

Releases.title: Volume 3
Releases.text: Rusuden’s Volume EPs continues with this next installment of tracks written with a revolving door of machines. While still being obsessed with old Roland boxes, he mixes their color & vibe with some Elektron & Waldorf characters to create a unique magic.  (For Meghan)

Releases.title: Manhattan
Releases.text: 8 techno tracks written in New York City from 2013 - 2015... under a haze of late night analog synthesis and hardware machine alchemy.

Releases.title: Squeeze / Squiggle
Releases.text: Digital split 'single' from Rusuden & Acean features acid & electro styles heard from their previous releases. Download includes 2 hidden remixes of one of our favorite artists.

Releases.title: Volume 2
Releases.text: Technically 'Acid Abyss' (Volume 2)... but I don't think the name fits anymore. These tracks were made around the same time as Volume 1 (2012/2013)... Created late at night. Really late. Each one started out with 1 synth and a drum machine, recorded straight to cassette. Then I went back and carved out the final track with other machines and edits. It's tough to remember all the machines... It's a nice mix of mostly analog boxes and a few digital ones. Really nice to finally release these tracks.

Releases.title: Machines II
Releases.text: Dystopian future tracks... All written in the Fall of 2014. Most were recorded directly to tape using a Tascam 112. These could be considered 'explorations in sampling', using found objects & sources in everyday life, to create the rhythm tracks. I recommend good speakers/headphones for sure. Laptop/Cellphone speakers won't give you the true picture.

Releases.title: Volna
Releases.text: Recorded during most of 2013, tracks 1-6 were inspired by older Sc-fi films and discussions with my Ukrainian friend, Irina. Themes were decided upon, her vocals were recorded and I continued to refine the best tracks from my recording sessions. All tracks made with a modest hardware-only setup: TR-808, Matrix 1000, SH-101, SH-2, Monomachine, Slim Phatty and Blofeld. However to give the best flexibility, a handful of software sequencers were used to control a couple synthesizers. These 6 tracks were mastered by the talented Shawn Hatfield at AudibleOddities in Oakland, California... using analog equipment only. Track 7 is a collection of experiments using hardware & software synthesizers from the past 3 or 4 years. From time to time, I'll spend an evening with a chosen piece of kit and let my mind meld with the instrument... pushing boundaries, exploring textures and recording the process. *Please note: There are ultra-low frequencies within. Watch your speakers & volume. Track 8 is a collection of tracks recorded in 2014 on three different airplanes over the course of 24 hours. Each piece was recorded live on a tablet computer, using a combination of various apps, in real-time using no overdubs. From Louisville to Chicago to Los Angeles to Auckland, I travelled into the future... missing a day completely in the process. These are the sounds during that time. This is Volna. It's a journey into space, to other worlds, crossing parallel dimensions, through wormholes... floating freely into the unknown. (Vocals by: Irina Goloborodko)

Releases.title: Seal Beach
Releases.text: 6 techno tracks written in Seal Beach, CA in 2012... under a haze of late night sound exploration and hardware machine wizardry.

Releases.title: October
Releases.text: October is a project where I merged my interest in the sounds of the acoustic guitar with my love for analog circuitry. Borrowing from techniques of musique concrète and granular synthesis, I also incorporated manipulated samples as melodies and rhythm. The end result sounds quite different compared to my recent “acid” tracks, and somewhat hints back to my earlier output from years ago. The journey, at times difficult, was refreshing and allowed pure creative freedom. I feel that the tracks which were selected for the final release honestly showcase my experience.  (Background percussion on tracks 4 and 8 by Scott Weber)

Releases.title: Acid Abyss (Vol 1)
Releases.text: Here's the first batch of tracks, taken from late night studio sessions. It's old machines playing nicely with new machines & software. Analog world meeting the digital one. Created quickly with the emphasis on texture & light/shadow. This is volume one.  (Live drums at end of track 2 by Scott Weber)

Releases.title: Lextown 303
Releases.text: Rusuden released this stunning A/B single as a farewell to Lexington, KY in 2014.  The title track provides a catchy acid number, complete with old-school video game samples.  It started as a jam with a TR-707 and TB-303… which was then crafted into the short & sweet 4min radio-friendly track.  The “b-side”, Cr02, is the balance to the overall tone of this release.  Originally a TR-808 and SH-101 late night jam, Justin waves goodbye to friends & loved ones as he heads to new experiences in multiple cities, far away.

Releases.title: Summer XII
Releases.text: Rusuden brings a new vibe to his catalog in 2012’s Summer XII.  The title track provides dance floor slamming with a TR-909 & SH-7 pounding the heart, and the MC-202 & TB-303 layering the acid woolliness in & out of existence. Junebug showcases a more stripped-down track with the TR-606 & SH-101 doing what they do best: acid.  This EP ends with Rain Storm 14 taken from an archive of sound experiments using analog synth gear with acoustic guitar.  Here the MC-202 is layered with a rain storm recorded from inside his apartment’s fireplace.

Releases.title: Summer XI
Releases.text: In 2011, Rusuden continued experimenting with his love of 90s dance music.  It’s probably save to assume the title track here was influenced by Orbital and their contemporaries.  A heavy TB-303 acid bassline is center to chirping cacophony.  Track 2, STS-135: Atlantis, uses the NASA provide audio track of the shuttle’s rocket boosters falling back to Earth once pushed away from the Orbiter.  Mixed with a TB-303 & MC-202, Rusuden gives the listener a dizzy, distorted experience to paint an image of what it’s like to have these massive structures fall back into our atmosphere.

Releases.title: Themes From A Distant Planetoid
Releases.text: Justin Morgan creates music under the name Rusuden. His musical output ranges from ambient, idm and breaks... to acid, house and techno. THEMES FROM A DISTANT PLANETOID sees Justin returning to calmer waters compared to his acid, techno tracks. Like the album Death By Din Sync, a host of vintage analog synths were used, however these songs feature digital machines such as Elektron’s Sidstation and Waldorf’s Q & Blofeld, as well as a Martin D-15 guitar. Cover art painted by Mary Spring.

Releases.title: Afterlife
Releases.text: Recorded in 2006... during a case of chronic fatigue for a few months. It's somewhat of a an ambient/minimal album... Album cover is a photo I took in high school, for photography class, of my friend at a local park/cemetery in Jacksonville, FL.

Releases.title: Death By Din Sync
Releases.text: In 2007 & 2008, Justin Morgan explored the world of vintage synths and drum machines for the first time.  With a lot of trial and error, he was able to get them connected and in sync with his computer to record handfuls of tracks using his “studio performance” style. His favorite tracks are represented here as Death By Din Sync, referencing the pre-MIDI technology to keep machines in time with one another. Primarily using vintage Roland and Korg machines, this release came about during the early stages of the analog revival from independent manufactures (ex: Dave Smith Instruments) and open source groups (ex: x0xb0x).  Their use and influence was also key to the overall tone and vibe.  (Photography by Nicholas Viltrakis)

Releases.title: Random Analog Transmissions
Releases.text: Rusuden presents: Random Analog Transmissions... a collection of demo tracks, showcasing some of my favorite synthesizers & drum machines. The collection was a 'work in progress' and is now complete.

Releases.title: Fe IX/X 171 A
Releases.text: For his latest musical escapade, Rusuden has his eyes set firmly on the dance floor. The snappily titled Fe IX/X 171 A, a scientific term relating to the process of imaging solar activity via ultraviolet light, features seven slices of unadulterated old school electro with subtle injections of acid and ambient, tempered with an ounce of Germanic minimalism. The mood evokes in turn the Richard D James of Polygon Window, early Ritchie Hawtin, B12 or early Black Dog even. Fe IX/X 171 A also marks a new creative peak for Rusuden. Clocking at just twenty-five minutes for seven tracks, Fe IX/X 171 A is a very concise and tight affair. Morgan’s delivery is confident and efficient. His soundscapes fuse classic electronic tones and futuristic vision, particularly on Snogon, Zanika or Takkong, whilst he engineers much coarser formations on tracks such as Yametarans or Yadokirin. The compositions work on a variety of levels, as different elements become obvious with repeat listens. Cold bleeps, acid squirts and regimented beats reveal hidden lush warm analogue soundwaves, secondary melodies and even occasional voices to complete Rusuden’s intricate tapestry. Morgan keeps rhythms and melodies fluid and fresh, and excellent sonic consistency, all the way through as he focuses on setting feet as much as mind in motion. - The Milk Factory

Releases.title: Fe IX/X 171 A
Releases.text: For his latest musical escapade, Rusuden has his eyes set firmly on the dance floor. The snappily titled Fe IX/X 171 A, a scientific term relating to the process of imaging solar activity via ultraviolet light, features seven slices of unadulterated old school electro with subtle injections of acid and ambient, tempered with an ounce of Germanic minimalism. The mood evokes in turn the Richard D James of Polygon Window, early Ritchie Hawtin, B12 or early Black Dog even. Fe IX/X 171 A also marks a new creative peak for Rusuden. Clocking at just twenty-five minutes for seven tracks, Fe IX/X 171 A is a very concise and tight affair. Morgan’s delivery is confident and efficient. His soundscapes fuse classic electronic tones and futuristic vision, particularly on Snogon, Zanika or Takkong, whilst he engineers much coarser formations on tracks such as Yametarans or Yadokirin. The compositions work on a variety of levels, as different elements become obvious with repeat listens. Morgan keeps rhythms and melodies fluid and fresh, and excellent sonic consistency, all the way through as he focuses on setting feet as much as mind in motion. - The Milk Factory

Releases.title: Z28
Releases.text: originally released in 2001 as a handmade CDR with dayglo green case & transparency artwork, created for shows and limited website sales. In 2006, a slightly different version was released with some crappy outtakes and different artwork (regular case, full color print). Now in 2014, this is the final version with 12 tracks total. (No case, digital only) Track 10 is a remix of Global Goon. He had a contest on his site or a forum, I can't remember. That's him playing the bass... I played all the guitar parts. I still love this remix. Track 11 is a remix of Multiplex. They had a similar deal... Track 12 is a remix of Whitetrash Shaolin. The are friends of mine, and this is my version of a fave track from their Fu Man Chaw release.

Releases.title: Warm Human Antennae
Releases.text: Warm Human Antennae, zips into a strange world where breakbeats, warm synths, guitar and even the acid bassline find a home... millions of miles away. With some tracks themed on visits to an alien, other world lounge - you can almost see the smoke trails come off the imported cigarettes from planet Earth. Elsewhere, a mixture of ambient guitar noodling drifts into a braindance drum kit jumble, where vocal snips fade into a multi-colored blend of sound.

Releases.title: Quiddity
Releases.text: Released under Justin’s own name, Quiddity is loosely based on ideas/feelings on Clive Barker’s novel: The Great and Secret Show.  Here, the mix of analog synthesizers and acoustic guitar are surrounded by a sea of noise and environmental change.  Is that train?  Is it rain?  Is that summer insects in Kentucky?  Cosm & Metacosm are tracks written with the amazing PerFourMer (mkI) by Vermona.  It’s a great sounding 4 part analog synth that gives some instant “Melodies From Mars” vibes.   The EP ends with End Credits which is driven by the Roland SH-5 in an out of tune rave world.
